qas.question: Why was the Kulluk oil rig being towed to Washington?

answers.text: to be serviced in preparation for the 2013 drilling season

qas.question: What caused towing crews and rescue service to lose control while the Kulluk rig was in transport to Washington?
On January 1, 2013, the Kulluk was grounded off the coast of which island?
Following the incident, which magazine contacted Larry McKinney?
Larry McKinney explained that a two-month delay in drilling could do what?

answers.text: wipe out the entire drilling season

qas.question: Where was the Kulluk oil rig being towed from?
Where was the Kullug grounded in December?
Who was the executive director of the Fortune magazine?
What magazine did Larry McKinney contact?
How long did it take to tow the Kulluk to Washington state?

context: As the Kulluk oil rig was being towed to <b5_0>the American state of Washington<b5_0/> <a0_0>to be serviced in preparation for the 2013 drilling season<a0_0/>, <a1_0>a winter storm<a1_0/> on 27 December 2012 caused the towing crews, as well as the rescue service, to lose control of the situation. As of 1 January 2013, the Kulluk was grounded off the coast <a2_0><b6_0>Sitkalidak<a2_0/> Island<b6_0/>, near the eastern end of Kodiak Island. Following the accident, a <a3_0><b8_0>Fortune<b8_0/><a3_0/> magazine contacted <b7_0>Larry McKinney<b7_0/>, the executive director at the Harte Research Institute for Gulf of Mexico Studies at Texas A&M, and he explained that "A <b9_0>two-month<b9_0/> delay in the Arctic is not a two-month delay ... A two-month delay could <a4_0>wipe out the entire drilling season<a4_0/>."
